comments.commentBody: Behind every great man is an even greater woman.

Perhaps the intended point. She loved him and loves him so much that she praises his virtues, even if not literally advertising him for the dating market? Is it not that, a celebration of life?

But none of us are perfect, and it does us little good to offer up true love as hazy vision of Prince Charming. Other people hurt terribly, but will end their lives alone.

Cancer is a robber, cancer is a thief -- but it has given you and all of your readers a small gift in exchange, awareness of the brevity and uncertainty of our next day. Thank you, Amy, and may those days given to you be bright with the love you and Jason share.

This is the most precious cry I have ever read in the Times.

Precious. As in affected and excessively delicate.

That poor Scott. Mind melding with the founding fathers yet he and the other Strength Through Unity Stand Strong crowd who could care less about foreign power interference in American elections are under attack by some Americans who know nothing about the Founders. So unlike Scott. A 2.59 gpa at Marquette with 96 credits gave him the mind meld ability to know what the Founders want today: him.

The poor dear. Bless his heart. He really believes he is that special. Anointed.

The ACA, for all its imperfections, is saving lives. It also has provided a mechanism to cushion the inevitable collapse of the pre-ACA system and facilitate the establishment of a more efficient and just successor. That will not be anything much like the GOP proposals.

Those who would collapse the ACA without a functional replacement will have blood on their hands. As a forty-year physician, I find that prospect repugnant, even if is not daunting to the Repuglican wing of the GOP. The current split in the GOP gives me hope that some of them share my concerns and are not themselves repugnant.

Ah,yes, college dropout Walker. He won both his gubernatorial races by slim majorities and was welcomed with open arms by Republican majorities in both houses of the legislature, majorities maintained by their gerrymandering now under challenge in the federal courts. His first act was to dismantle collective bargaining for state and local public employees, which he gleefully referred to as "dropping the bomb" on public employees like teachers whom he has constantly belittled. Later he was overheard boasting about his political strategy to a billionaire donor as "divide and conquer." This is what he considers "going high."

Walker has made historic cuts in k-12 public education that have devastated all but the most affluent school districts over his two terms while expanding vouchers statewide to private and religious schools. Not just rural schools are hurting, sad to say.

I don't know that "Republicans, ignore your constituents" is the advice I'd give our elected representatives, but perhaps Scott Walker is more savvy than I. After all, he's gotten elected, even though I don't understand how.

How elected officials, whose salary, healthcare, and other benefits are provided by the very taxpayers they so disdain, can hold citizens in such disregard is beyond me.

"They should be employed or enrolled in job training, looking for work five times a week and able to pass a drug test. If they fail, we would get them into rehab and into the work force." Oh, let's see if rehab costs less than decent food, shelter and clothing, which, by the way, are also provided in rehab.  No Gov. Walker, what you want are slaves working for "the man" only this time it's big government at the state level.  All the while Reps complain about the national government interfering with people's lives and businesses, the states pass law after law interfering with people's lives and businesses. Shame. Bigly.

Walker is a small minded puppet of wealthy extremists who finance his right wing beat down of the poor and middle class.  He hasn't had an original thought in his life, but he imagines himself as a great innovator; in fact, he offers nothing but tired and failed conservative nostrums.  The result is a state with crumbling roads, a brain drain getting worse all the time, schools that can't find teachers willing to work here, a shrunken middle class - and a governor with a sub- forty percent approval rating.  He fancies himself a tough guy staring down violent protesters, but he's a cowardly pipsqeak who has never appeared at anything other than tightly controlled photo ops with sycophantic supporters. He's couldn't even win an argument with a mental midget like Trump.

If states had been willing to address healthcare deficits the Obama administration wouldn't have had to step in and do it for them. That's part of the problem with the Republican philosophy: they may say they want states to be the ones to solve the problems, but do they actually do anything when the ball is in their court? No! Republicans I've talked to online tell me they want road maintenance done by the states, but it already is, it's just that their shitty state government doesn't get anything done and blames it on the federal government.

If Wisconsin is so desperate for workers without drug problems why don't you create programs to get people clean and redirect them away from using in the first place? Oh wait, that would involve actually being useful for a change, heaven forbid Republican state governments do that, that costs money and Republicans are too busy cutting taxes to have any.

I had no idea that all those folks who were protesting your leadership and now protesting Trump were doing so because they want the power and money to be in D.C. Gee, it seems incredible that so many folks would boycott the inauguration and then have all those women  show up in D.C. because they passionately want D.C. and the Federal Government to control tax money and power and more importantly, their lives.  COme to think of it, if the Feds had left us alone in the last century, we could still enjoy our cars without the need for all those fussy anti pollution controls, occupant cash restraints, and other annoying safety concerns that add costs.  And, with power going back to the states, all those nasty demonstrators can enjoy the wonders of voter restrictions, and advantages of ER wards as your party's age old answer to universal health care.  And since you mentioned your sainted Ronnie, I suggest you listen to his 1961 recorded chat on just how unAmerican those greedy Democrats are for wanting to establish programs like Medicare... and, perhaps some states would establish debtors prisons -- wow, now there's an idea that someone like you could innovate.

As an Alabama native, I am well-versed in the arguments for states' rights.  Walker seems to say, "If only the federal government would stop pestering states with that Constitution, look what we could do."  I've heard these arguments before. The legacies of governors like George Wallace and Lestor Maddox, as well as senators like Jesse Helms and Strom Thurmond, live on today in Wisconsin.

Mr. Walker is clear in declaring that he is the governor of conservative Wisconsin alone. That 100,000 were animated enough to vocalize their horror at his policies means nothing. Fortunately, he did not have the chance to replicate his ruinous experiment on the country. Meanwhile, the left needs to recognize there is no governing partner on the right. Fight the Kochs, Walkers, and Bannons with everything possible.

Progressives are abandoning free speech and shouting down, intimidating, shaming, and threatening those with other views. Those who believe in rule of law and freedom of speech must stand together to face down this rising mob mentality.

Speakers at meeting deserve respect, and to be heard. Each of us can speak, in our turn. Shouting down those with the mic is just chaos and a rejection of democratic ideals.

Absolute nonsense!  We have seen time and time again that states misappropriated block grant dollars,and that most still have little idea of how to manage a competitive insurance market.  This will lead to Republican Death Panels as lower and even middle  income people and seniors Wil not be able to afford coverage, or they will select lower cost coverage which will no longer cover even basic preventive services.  People will die from neglect and their deaths will be in your hands.

If we keep extending this "give power back to the states" concept, we will soon become the un-United States of America.  The economic, legal and political disparities among states are becoming greater and greater with every law passed by state legislatures on matters of marijuana, transgender rights, right to unionize, etc.  As people gravitate to states that conform best to their world views, the country will become ever more polarized and divided. Is this the Republican vision of greatness for America, a weak and emasculated federal government? I'm not buying.

Protesters are not American citizens?  Shouldn't elected officials pay attention to them?  Is Walker calling for standing strong against those whom they should serve regardless the protesters are liberals, conservatives or taxpayers?  If it is up to the GOP with mess tax cuts, building the "beautiful" wall, increase of defense Department budget, etc, our national debt will be sky-rocking, and those who receive social services will suffer, our environment will be polluted.  Yes, Republicans, stand strong, and we will see you out of office in 2018!

Gov. Scott Walker considers protests to be an "intimidation" tactic. But later he says "This is how our Founding Fathers envisioned our country." Our Founding Fathers and our Constitution support and defend peaceful protesting, Gov. Walker, and did not see protesting as a form of intimidation but rather as a means for the people YOU represent to express themselves.

Instead of acknowledging that 100,000 constituents of his were trying to be heard, Gov. Walker instead considered them to be intimidators to be ignored, his own citizens.

Bragging about quashing teachers. Big of you, Gov. Walker. Wisconsin teachers earn less than the national average for teachers. And here is Walker boasting about making sure it stays that way, calling them "intimidators".

And as usual, a Republican declares his/her interpretation of Founding Fathers' intent, Constitutional intent, etc., to be the only one, the correct one, no doubt making him a "real American", as right wingers have for years now been saying they are, even as they are now defending illegal hacking to interfere with a US election by a US enemy.

And God forbid a Republican ever make an argument without resorting to the manipulative tactic of invoking Ronald Reagan's name. Not everyone believes Reagan was good fort his country, Gov. Walker. Anyone who believes his trickle-down economics has had a positive outcome probably shouldn't be making arguments for anything else, as it shows that person has no credibility.

"Americans were given a choice in November......... Their clear answer in 2016 was “not Washington.”
I would like to remind Governor Walker that the Democratic candidate for President, Hillary Clinton, defeated President Trump by 3 million votes and that the Democrats received more total votes for their congressional candidates than did the Republicans. In addition, the President's current approval rating is a woeful 43% and the Congress' is much worse.. But the real issue is the boundaries of the 48 states in the contiguous United States. The absurd borders of the states are artificial and completely unrelated to the geographical, climate, topographical, social, economic, political, cultural, and historical forces that drive the nation. Thus the inexplicable argument that prevented a badly needed rail tunnel being built under the Hudson River connecting New York City with New Jersey, the inability to buy health insurance across artificial state lines, the corruption of our national electoral process that has produced two minority president in the last sixteen years, the costly and useless duplication and redundancies of 48 state governments, the unhelpful disparities in state taxation, the composition of the US Senate where a state like Delaware, with under one million people, has the same number of US Senators as California with 40 million people. And this doesn't even begin to address the primitive ideology that Governor Walker is an advocate of.

Please include Illinois, which voted overwhelming for Clinton though this state is divided, like many others, between blue urban areas and red rural ones. Illinois, as it happens, is an example of a state in conflict because a Republican gov is standing so strong (like Walker, against unions) that we havent had a budget in 2.5 years, Chicago's been robbed of its $ for the public schools, social services throughout the state are getting cut and vendors going unpaid. Too bad financial whiz Rauner wont ask for a microtax on stock trades. Luckily he's facing election next year. And when is Walker being voted on again?

Return power to the states? It's the states that failed the desperate voters who supported this train wreck. The very same states that implemented policies like those you champion are the states in which these voters live, and they're looking to the federal government to help them because their state governments abandoned them. Do you think it's a coincidence that voters in Massachusetts and California don't feel like they're suffering? No. It's because our states support taxation as a means for creating a just and civilized society. What have the 33 states with republican governors done for working people? Busted unions? That helps the wealthy, whose taxes you cut. And don't take credit for the increase in jobs. There are more jobs everywhere since we recovered from the financial crisis brought to us by the moneyed interests. Obama's stimulus Brought back jobs. Financial austerity? That worked well in Kansas! Draconian laws on social issues? Backfired in Indiana and NC. Defy the messages delivered by protesters at your peril. 2018 is right around the corner, and the army of GOTV volunteers will match the attendance at the women's March.

I will overlook the dangling clause to comment that more people are working in Wisconsin than ever before and that is the case in all the states because under President Obama the economy was growing. If in Wisconsin employers are begging for workers with "basic skills" who are drug-free, should they find them they will be be especially happy to put them in non-unionized jobs and pay them less than a living wage, courtesy of the wisdom of the state legislature.

We all want to have it both ways. We want protesters to be heard when their protests are justified in our minds, but we don't want elected officials to cave in to protesters when their cause is, in our minds, bad.

All-purpose protests, like the great Women's March, are not intended to change a specific piece of legislation or promote a specific cause. They are for the benefit of the participants, let them feel their collective strength, to energize them for the fights to come, a coming together in solidarity, like a Fourth of July parade. They may serve to a lesser extent as a means to inform elected officials that there are people in numbers passionately opposed to some of their policies, and willing to do something about it.

Walker, in this piece, says that "Republicans Must Stand Strong." And so they must. And so must Democrats. Unless "standing strong" means "always demanding what the people who support me want, never compromising, and to hell with everyone else." That kind of standing strong is what has gotten this country in its present mess.

No, governor Walker, Republicans ought not to "stand strong" if standing strong mean ignoring that fact that Democrats exist, trampling on the rights of individuals and minority groups, and generally serving some people at the expense of others.

Though I strongly doubt it, perhaps one day Mr. Walker will accept that there are segments of the population that simply cannot provide for themselves in the manner or to the degree he envisions; as such, the states will never be able to adequarely assist them without the federal programs he desperately wants to slash. What is the equitable solution? I am not sure, but the moral one mandates that the most vulnerable and needy among us recieve enough help to maintain their health and well-being; anything short of that must be seen as unacceptable.
